headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mattel, Inc. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Martin Gilkes, Vice President,
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Mattel, Inc. First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Martin Gilkes, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sabrina, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Chris Sinclair, Mattel's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Richard Dickson, Mattel's President and Chief Operating Officer; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's Chief Financial Officer. As you
componenttext:
Thank you, Sabrina, and good afternoon, everyone. Joining me today are Chris Sinclair, Mattel's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Richard Dickson, Mattel's President and Chief Operating Officer; and Kevin Farr, Mattel's Chief Financial Officer. As you know, this afternoon, we reported Mattel's 2016 first quarter financial results. We will begin today's call with Chris, Richard and Kevin providing commentary and our results, and then we'll take your questions. 
To help guide our discussion today, we have provided you with a slide presentation. Both our earnings release and slide presentation include non-GAAP financial measures. The information required by Regulation G regarding non-GAAP financial measures is included in these materials and both documents are available on the investors section of our corporate website, corporate.mattel.com. 
Before we begin, I'd like to remind you that certain statements made during the call may include forward-looking statements relating to the future performance of our overall business, brands and product lines. These statements are based on currently available information and they are subject to a number of significant risks and uncertainties that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those projected on the forward-looking statements. We describe some of these uncertainties in the Risk Factors section of our 2015 annual report on Form 10-K, our 2015 quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and other filings we make with the SEC from time to time as well as in our other public statements. Mattel does not update forward-looking statements and expressly disclaims any obligation to do so. 
Now I'd like to turn the call over to Chris.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Martin, and welcome, everyone. I'd like to thank you for joining us. Today, I'm going to lead things off with a brief perspective on both the quarter and the full year, and then Richard and Kevin will each provide some additional details. And as u
componenttext:
Thanks, Martin, and welcome, everyone. I'd like to thank you for joining us. Today, I'm going to lead things off with a brief perspective on both the quarter and the full year, and then Richard and Kevin will each provide some additional details. And as usual, we'll open things up at the end for any questions you might have. 
So let me begin by saying that overall, we're very encouraged by the start of the year and particularly with our ability to hold the top line as we offset the loss of Disney Princess. We also made some good progress against our cost reduction goals, both in cost of goods and in SG&A. The offsetting negative, of course, continues to be significant headwinds in foreign exchange, both in translation and transaction, which depressed our gross margins in the quarter. We also recorded a $26 million charge and other income to recognize adjustments from Venezuela's currency devaluation, which I think most of you know has severely impacted most corporations with operations in that country. Putting aside foreign exchange, the net message is that we continue to make good progress on our strategic priorities, and we also remain on track to execute well and to deliver on our outlook for this year. We're certainly setting up well to restore real growth in 2017 and beyond. 
Our shipments in POS were closely aligned in this quarter, with POS positive and shipments off slightly in constant currency. We were also encouraged by solid POS trends on key core brands like Barbie, Fisher-Price and Hot Wheels and by a number of our key brands within the Toy Box. Importantly, our retail space also stabilized versus last year and shelf productivity has remained strong, which we expect will support some expansion opportunities on shelf space this fall. We'll also continue to execute well broadly across much of our customer base. And to this latter point, while North America remains a good leading indicator of our progress with positive shipping in the quarter, we're also seeing some fairly broad-based strength across most regions and, particularly, in our emerging markets. 
Now for the middle of the P&L, we also made some good progress and we do remain on track with our cost targets, the performance of which was largely massed, at least in gross margin, by the impact of currencies. And here, it's important to point out that on a constant currency basis, gross margin was actually relatively stable. Looking ahead, we expect the cost savings to accelerate through the balance of the year. We also expect the seasonal impacts from foreign exchange and from the loss of Disney Princess to begin to mitigate. And that, we're still tracking to our expectations.  
Finally, I'll note that our balance sheet remains strong. We're continuing to invest in the business and to maintain our dividend. So to summarize, we're encouraged and we remain cautiously optimistic about the way the year is setting up. It's early and we still have a lot of work ahead, but we're executing well, our entertainment drivers and most of our important brands are performing. We're expanding rapidly in key emerging markets and we're getting out the cost that we expect it to. A little help from foreign exchange would be nice as well, but we do think we have this accounted for as we move through the year. 
So what this all means is we continue to see things taking shape much as we communicated to you in February at Toy Fair. Our outlook for 2016 is largely unchanged and we're tracking well for strong performance next year. 
And with that as a set up, let me turn things over to Richard to highlight some of our topline progress and our core initiatives, and he'll be followed by Kevin, who will give you a lot more color on our performance and on our outlook. Richard?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. As Chris said, we're making progress on many fronts, with lots of positive indicators of our success, not the least of which is the attention Mattel's transformation is receiving worldwide. Consumers and the media are once again focused
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. As Chris said, we're making progress on many fronts, with lots of positive indicators of our success, not the least of which is the attention Mattel's transformation is receiving worldwide. Consumers and the media are once again focused on our brands and our products rather than our challenges. And while much of the attention we've been receiving has revolved around key strategic priorities, we attribute our success largely to quarter after quarter of solid execution. And our first quarter execution demonstrates that we're off to a good start with consumer Takeaway and Shipping, giving us even more confidence that we can achieve our 2016 goal to hold the topline relatively flat in constant currency. 
Let's review some specifics. We were pleased to see continued positive global POS up 2% normalizing for the Easter holiday with considerable POS strength in international markets. One of the most encouraging stats this quarter is that we almost completely offset the loss of the Disney Princess license, which represented about $100 million or 10% of last year's sales. This was accomplished through great execution across the entire organization. And when the impact of Disney Princess is excluded, Mattel's positive POS performance improved significantly to the mid-single digits, with shipping up high single digits. It wasn't that long ago when we began to transform the company's culture and reset our approach to brand management with the creation of our core brand teams and the Toy Box organization. While recognizing we have more work to do, the first quarter results continues to demonstrate our conviction to fundamentally change our approach to the business. These trends also continue to validate our strategic initiatives, ongoing revitalization of our core brands, the rebuilding of our relationships with strategic license partners, accelerated growth in emerging markets and a much more effective presence at retail. 
So let's take a closer look at results. Overall, our strong holiday season led to reduced retail inventories on key brands and we were encouraged by retailer confidence in our business as they look to restock their shelves with Mattel products in the first quarter. Excluding the impact of Forex, we saw strong shipping numbers on many of our brands, including Barbie, Fisher-Price, Hot Wheels, Thomas and MEGA Brands. And we saw strong consumer and retail support for our new DC Comics executions. We continue to be pleased with Barbie's performance coming off such a strong holiday season with global POS and shipping closely aligned in the first quarter. As you know, last year, we were essentially relaunching and Barbie and saw tremendous results, particularly in the U.S. where POS was up double digits. And from that new base, we continue to see positive POS here in the U.S. And with shipping up 11%, we are also beginning to see this momentum broaden with positive Barbie POS in Europe and Asia. Now we have more work to do, but we will continue to build on the brand's resurgence in North America and the very strong response we are seeing with our Barbie marketing strategy and new breadth of product. We will also be increasing our successful marketing to moms to drive brand preference. Looking forward, expect us to build on the successes, many exciting innovations, including those you saw recently at Toy Fair. We're confident that Barbie will only become more engaging and relevant to girls and moms as we move forward toward holiday 2016. 
But remember, Mattel is not just a Barbie story. Fisher-Price results for the quarter reflect positive POS trends with very strong shipping. We were pleased to see our biggest segment, Baby, have particularly solid POS and shipping in the quarter, notably in international markets. We're seeking to accelerate that momentum as we continue to emphasize early childhood development, the most important demand driver in the category today. We've already seen a tremendous response to our new Think and Learn line with the widely-anticipated Code-a-Pillar product set to launch later this year. 
In addition, earlier this month, we're excited to formally announce the appointment of one of today's most popular designers, Jonathan Adler, as creative director for the Fisher-Price brand. You'll begin to see his influence this fall and we are hard at work leveraging his unique understanding of lifestyle aesthetics for today's families with more sophisticated Fisher-Price style, fashion and function for 2017. 
Thomas and Hot Wheels each continue to see solid POS and shipping trends, particularly in international markets. Both brands have exciting new content and products this year to support the strong momentum we're seeing on these brands. 
Now as we said in February, American Girl results will be challenging in the first half of this year as the major new initiatives to generate positive brand momentum will be coming online in the third and fourth quarters. We continue to take meaningful steps to energize this brand. And as I mentioned in our last update, there are some specific price value issues that we are addressing as well as an improved distribution and expanded consumer engagement. I'll be sharing more on these as the year progresses. 
Monster High has yet to stabilize. Despite some success with our new offerings, the decline in POS and competitive product launches have impacted its shelf space and overall performance. Consumer engagement continues to build with this brand with over 2 million subscribers on Facebook, over 800,000 monthly visits to the website and a significant growth in views on YouTube. Our focus remains on how to connect this great brand energy with more toys sales. As you know, we are effectively relaunching the brand in the second half of this year with a new look, new content, a refocus on popular core characters, more features and enhanced play value. We remain cautiously optimistic, but realistically hope to see improving POS trends in the second half of the year, which will be a leading indicator that the brand is stabilizing as we exit 2016. 
Turning now to Toy Box. We've been very encouraged by early consumer demand for our new DC Super Hero Girls line, even though some of its content just went live late in Q1. While currently an exclusive launch at target, its retail presence will go broader in June. On a related note, we are very pleased with the initial response our DC superheroes Batman v Superman product with the blockbuster film premiering the last week of the quarter. And we're excited to watch how this franchise builds as we continue to support the extensive upcoming DC movie slate. 
And lastly, I'd like to highlight the solid performance of MEGA Brands construction globally. We continue to see very strong results with MEGA's preschool executions, our own brand overlays at Monster High and American Girl as well as the initial popularity of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles product lined ahead of the June movie release. 
Overall, I am pleased with the company's performance. I'm proud of the continuing progress in resetting Mattel's culture to be more innovative, more competitive and more efficient. We have both significant opportunities and significant challenges to face this year and I'm encouraged by our execution to date and look forward to reporting more progress to you throughout the year. As Chris said, our progress to date has generated strong momentum to build on and we are increasingly well-positioned for growth and greater profitability in 2017 and beyond. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Kevin Farr. Kevin?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Richard, and good afternoon, everyone. As Chris said, foreign exchange continues to negatively impact our financial results in the first quarter. Overall, our results were in line with our expectations. Specifically, we're encouraged by our top
componenttext:
Thank you, Richard, and good afternoon, everyone. As Chris said, foreign exchange continues to negatively impact our financial results in the first quarter. Overall, our results were in line with our expectations. Specifically, we're encouraged by our top line performance as growth in our revenues of our core brands and Toy Box almost fully offset the loss of the Disney Princess license. We also made significant progress on executing our cost savings programs, which resulted in roughly flat year-over-year operating margin on a reported basis. 
Before going into detail, I want to remind everyone that unless otherwise noted, I'll be referring to sales in constant currency and adjusted financial results that exclude certain items related to our acquisitions of MEGA, Fuhu and Sproutling as well as severance expense. So highlighting the topline trends, gross sales were down just 1% in constant currency or 6% as reported. This included growth in North America and Europe despite the loss of the Disney Princess license business. 
We continue to see double-digit growth in China, but our Asia-Pacific region declined modestly, primarily due to Australia. Latin America also declined as Mexico continues to deliver solid growth, but our business in Brazil has been impacted by macroeconomic weakness, pricing challenges and inventory overhang. And of course, the underlying trends looks much more favorable when we exclude Disney Princess with overall gross sales up high single digits for the quarter. This included broad-based growth across all regions except Latin America, where sales were flat. Overall, very solid topline performance on an underlying basis. These early leads are very encouraging as continued strong growth in our core brands and Toy Box revenues are the key for us to achieve our goal of relatively flat sales for the full year. 
Moving to the rest of the P&L, sales adjustments were relatively flat versus the prior year as a percentage of net sales where we continue to invest in retail promotions to drive POS and shipping for the first quarter and full year. As Chris said, our gross margin was relatively flat year-over-year in constant currency but 44.7% as reported. As we said in our 2016 outlook, we expect foreign exchange to be a headwind for the full year. We expected that particularly in the first half on a gross margin rate basis due to the seasonality quarters and tougher year-over-year comparisons. And we saw this in the first quarter with around 340 of the 410 basis point decline in gross margins attributable to unfavorable foreign exchange. Almost half the negative impact from foreign exchange could be explained by less favorable euro hedging rates in 2016 versus 2015. Another driver is the fact that we're selling inventory that was produced last year at less favorable rates when the dollar significantly strengthened against key currencies. 
In the first quarter, we also saw strong trends in growth in countries with more volatile currencies like Mexico and Russia versus 2015. Looking forward, we expect this to balance out, particularly in the second half of the year with higher seasonal revenues. 
The other key driver of the decline in gross margin rate in the quarter was related to mix shift from our higher-margin dollar business given, the loss of Disney Princess to lower-margin product lines like MEGA and Fisher-Price. And finally, as it relates to our overall gross margin, what's encouraging is that our cost savings initiatives more than offset inflation while continuing to improve our price value proposition. 
Moving beyond gross margin, advertising was lower as we begin to move somewhat closer to the 12% for the full year coupled with the benefit of foreign exchange. On a positive note, adjusted SG&A was down $25 million or 7% year-over-year as cost savings and favorable foreign exchange more than offset labor-related inflation. In total, we deliver gross cost savings of $46 million in the quarter, roughly evenly split between the gross margins and SG&A. 
Finally, adjusted EPS was a negative $0.13 per share or negative $0.21 as reported. As some of you may know in February, the Venezuelan government change its official exchange rate, which reprompted a devaluation this quarter. As a result, reported EPS included a $0.06 negative impact from the remeasurement of our Bolivar denominated assets primarily cash in Venezuela, which we excluded from adjusted EPS. 
As it relates to our balance sheet and cash flow, we ended the quarter with around $600 million in cash, a similar quarter-over-quarter change to where we ended the fourth quarter of 2015. This was in line with our expectations and reflects solid performance, especially when you consider the roughly $30 million cash [indiscernible] for the acquisition of Fuhu and Sproutling and roughly $20 million reduction in cash due to the Venezuelan devaluation. 
Not surprisingly, owned inventory on our balance sheet was up year-over-year as we position the business to support our new licensed entertainment launches throughout the year in addition to the continued positive POS trends in the global basis, including great momentum into launches for MEGA. 
Receivables were also up due to the later timing of the customer shipments as well as the impact of longer term for some of our emerging market customers. We did see a benefit this quarter from our efforts around extending key vendor terms to match industry norms over the last 2 years with the latest extension implemented in May of 2015. This favorability should moderate going forward based on the timing when we implemented these changes in 2015. However, we'll continue to emphasize even greater overall discipline in accounts payable management going forward as we continue to reward our shareholders by deploying capital in a disciplined manner and maintaining the dividend. As we've said, dividends remain our first priority after reinvesting in the business. And the board declared a second quarter dividend of $0.38 per share, which is flat compared to the second quarter of 2015. 
As we look ahead to our second quarter and full year 2016 outlook, we're targeting gross sales in the second quarter to reflect similar year-over-year trends to what we achieved in the first quarter or relatively flat on a constant currency basis. Although Disney Princess comparisons get easier, we believe there's some benefit in the first quarter from initial retail destocking of Mattel products due to low beginning inventory levels on shelf. Offsetting this is earlier results from key incremental revenue drivers, which looks promising, and this momentum should continue in the second quarter and beyond. 
As it relates to gross margin, we believe the second quarter gross margin rate will be roughly flat to the first quarter with supply chain efficiencies and cost savings partially offsetting foreign exchange headwinds. And we believe we'll continue to see year-over-year savings on adjusted SG&A in the second quarter driven by continued efficiencies in cost savings initiatives. However, the year-over-year improvement will be less than what we saw in Q1 in part due to the full quarter addition of Fuhu SG&A. As such, we expect second quarter adjusted SG&A spending to be modestly down versus the first quarter run rate in dollars.  
Finally, despite a significant first half headwinds, our full year P&L outlook for 2016 remains unchanged. I'll briefly focus on the key drivers. We're still looking to deliver relatively flat net sales in constant currency. On gross margin, we continue to target about 50% for the full year, similar to what we achieved in 2015. Specifically, there are 2 key drivers of first half headwinds that should moderate in the second half. The first is foreign exchange. Assuming current spot rates and our current hedge position, for reference, foreign exchange had roughly positive 100 basis point impact to gross margin rate in the first half of 2015 versus roughly a negative 200 basis point impact to gross margin rate in the second half. For the second half of the year, we expect the impact of foreign exchange to moderate as seasonal revenues are significantly higher in the second half. The hedge euro rate differential for the second half is closer to hedge rate for 2015. Country mix should balance out. We offset some of the foreign exchange with price increases on the fall line and easier year-over-year gross margin rate comparisons. 
The second factor is mix. As we look to the second half, we expect that the negative impact of Disney Princess mix will lessen since it's smaller relative to our overall revenues, and we should see the benefit from expected growth in our doll business, including Barbie, the global launch of DC Superheroes and strong initiatives on American Girl. And importantly, as we ramp up production in the second quarter and work towards peak production, we expect structural supply chain savings to accelerate, which will be positive gross margin for the second half. 
Lastly, we continue to target adjusted SG&A to be down $55 million to $65 million year-over-year. Our previous outlook excluded SG&A, Fuhu and Sproutling, which we have recently acquired. However, we'll look to absorb the bulk of the overhead from Fuhu and Sproutling acquisitions by aggressively pursuing additional cost savings opportunities. 
Finally, looking beyond this year of transition as Chris said, we see a path to approaching our 15% to 20% operating margin target in 2017 as we have a tailwind on top line revenues from Cars 3 movie and continued traction in China, Russia and emerging markets. Beyond the key drivers already discussed, Fuhu and Sproutling will help offset the earnings impact related to the increased SG&A in 2016, but we expect sales to ramp up in 2017 as we leverage the technology platform across the portfolio and expand our market opportunities. 
In closing, we don't want to get ahead of ourselves in this seasonally small quarter, but the turnaround continues to track to our expectations. Our global POS remains positive, which is driving further shelf space stabilization for key core brands and a shipping recovery across most of our regions when you exclude Disney Princess. If these trends continue, it should set a solid foundation for growth and improved profitability in 2017. 
We look forward to updating you on the core progress throughout the year, and we'll now open the call up to questions. Operator?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

componenttextpreview: I'm curious if you guys would be willing to talk about the contribution from the DC Comics relationship? Obviously, entertainment has been pretty lucrative for Hasbro and I'm curious how the readthrough has been for you guys so far.
componenttext: I'm curious if you guys would be willing to talk about the contribution from the DC Comics relationship? Obviously, entertainment has been pretty lucrative for Hasbro and I'm curious how the readthrough has been for you guys so far.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we mentioned, we're really pleased with the early read right now of DC Super Hero Girls collection, exclusive at Target currently, but we'll have a broader roll out in June. And we anticipate continued momentum through the year that potentially a much
componenttext: As we mentioned, we're really pleased with the early read right now of DC Super Hero Girls collection, exclusive at Target currently, but we'll have a broader roll out in June. And we anticipate continued momentum through the year that potentially a much longer franchise at that they continue to introduce new characters into the mix. In addition, as we also mentioned, coming off of the blockbuster hits at this point where the Batman v Superman, the toy business is reacting really terrific. We continue to see momentum behind that segment and, as you know, we have a really robust lineup over the next several years with Warner Bros. and DC. So we are looking forward to continuing to grow that franchise over all and currently really pleased with initial readings.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then can you -- I don't know if you guys have done this to your team but can you talk about how you think about your integrating some of the digital ideas from either Fuhu or Sproutling into the product lines? And what sort of prototypes we migh
componenttext: Okay. And then can you -- I don't know if you guys have done this to your team but can you talk about how you think about your integrating some of the digital ideas from either Fuhu or Sproutling into the product lines? And what sort of prototypes we might see coming out of this acquisitions?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jamie, I'll take that. I think we've got a very active team working on integrating it at this point. A lot of work being done to sort of integrate both Fuhu and Sproutling with some of the Fisher-Price lines. I think we'll probably be rolling some things
componenttext: Jamie, I'll take that. I think we've got a very active team working on integrating it at this point. A lot of work being done to sort of integrate both Fuhu and Sproutling with some of the Fisher-Price lines. I think we'll probably be rolling some things out in the fourth quarter this year principally in China as a lead market, but all designed to go after early childhood development, sort of a nursery of the future, if you will, getting a lot of excitement and interest on that front. Additionally, we're doing a lot of things with the Fuhu learning platform, so we'll start to roll out a little bit more of this fall on their tablet business. But we think actually have some great applications with some partners we're working on, again, starting in Asia. But the early read on both is very exciting, and I think they're integral actually to the whole channels and development platform were going after on Fisher-Price principally. There's another benefit that I would highlight is that we're going to have these toys with sort of connected homes and the nurseries, which obviously will give us a great pipeline of data that we can help to manage and mind for consumer marketing. So another sort of key benefit to these acquisitions.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kevin, I know you give a little bit of color regarding gross margin, and I wonder if you can just talk a little bit again about the back half of the year. It seems like you're implying a 52%, 53% gross margin in the third and fourth quarters. It's been a
componenttext: Kevin, I know you give a little bit of color regarding gross margin, and I wonder if you can just talk a little bit again about the back half of the year. It seems like you're implying a 52%, 53% gross margin in the third and fourth quarters. It's been a long time since we've seen gross margins that high. Is it just the fact that you're going to see more girls doll business or is there other factors involved in that?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I'll be happy to answer that. So we are still targeting gross margins of 50% [ph] for the year as I said, similar to the amount that we achieved last year. And that means a moderate year-over-year improvement in our second half gross margin rate ver
componenttext: Okay, I'll be happy to answer that. So we are still targeting gross margins of 50% [ph] for the year as I said, similar to the amount that we achieved last year. And that means a moderate year-over-year improvement in our second half gross margin rate versus last year, where we achieved gross margins of about 50%. And based upon the current spot rates and hedge rates, we believe it's achievable and well within our 3- to 5-year historical averages. But how we achieved in 2016 will be a little bit different than how we achieved it in our historical averages, would rely more on pricing and better mix. As we look at the second half of the year, we're going to really achieve it through acceleration of cost of goods sold, through supply-chain structural changes, which don't impact our price value propositions. So it's going to be more about accelerating cost savings on structure supply chain in the second half of the year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: There will be some positive mix shift versus the first half of the year, which start to come under effect. And I think he also pointed out, we do expect Forex to moderate as we move into the back half. So we're getting a lot of those things. I think, we'r
componenttext: There will be some positive mix shift versus the first half of the year, which start to come under effect. And I think he also pointed out, we do expect Forex to moderate as we move into the back half. So we're getting a lot of those things. I think, we're comfortable getting somewhere close to that 50% target.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's very helpful. And as a follow-up, you pointed to contributions from Toy Box is being a key driver this year. And can you just go through again what have been some of those successes from Toy Box that have got you excited?
componenttext: Okay, that's very helpful. And as a follow-up, you pointed to contributions from Toy Box is being a key driver this year. And can you just go through again what have been some of those successes from Toy Box that have got you excited?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Toy back is a myriad of brands, as you know. Certainly, our licensed partnership brands are in there as well as a variety of other brands and properties within Mattel. Specifically, we've had some great POS and traction on our games business. UNO co
componenttext: Sure. Toy back is a myriad of brands, as you know. Certainly, our licensed partnership brands are in there as well as a variety of other brands and properties within Mattel. Specifically, we've had some great POS and traction on our games business. UNO continues to grow and is a legacy brand in our portfolio, and the team there is doing incredibly job of keeping that brand relevant and driving units. MEGA continues to be outstanding for us overall at a great quarter internationally specifically, as well as the U.S. We continue to get traction both in the preschool segment as well as leveraging our owned properties, American Girl, Monster High and then, of course, as we anticipate the launch of the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles movie. We think that we're going to have a great get there. Brands like Minecraft also continue to be really terrific and the team is doing an excellent job maintaining the relevance of that brand and brands like Dinotrux with our partnership with DreamWorks. Blaze also with Nickelodeon is doing terrific. There's a lot of great brands within Toy Box that are continuing to be nurtured and developed and are frankly chipping away at our GAAP but ultimately driving some great growth in their own right. As we continue to develop the strategic partnership profile, not only will we do continue job driving our existing, but we continue to see new relationships as well as with existing relationships. So going forward, Cars, of course, 3, which we've talked about, lining up in 2018 with Toy Story and others will be revealed shortly.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Arpine Kocharyan of UBS.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Arpine Kocharyan of UBS.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit about POS for the quarter? The global POS improvement you talked about, is that adjusted for Disney? Is it possible to give us at least U.S. Disney adjusted and Easter adjusted in terms of POS?
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit about POS for the quarter? The global POS improvement you talked about, is that adjusted for Disney? Is it possible to give us at least U.S. Disney adjusted and Easter adjusted in terms of POS?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. What we can tell you is that Disney, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, has performed very well, up single digit increases worldwide. It's commensurate with our shipping numbers as well. Across our core brand portfolio, we see more pos
componenttext: This is Richard. What we can tell you is that Disney, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, has performed very well, up single digit increases worldwide. It's commensurate with our shipping numbers as well. Across our core brand portfolio, we see more positives than not. In fact, in cases like Hot Wheels across the board, we've seen both shipping and POS really strong results. I mentioned Fisher-Price had a really strong quarter, both in shipping and POS. Brands like Barbie, of courses, turning the corner and gaining more and more momentum. U.S. was strong performer. Europe is now reflecting positive POS as well as Asia and we continue to work on Latin America. And ex the Disney Princess business, we're performing quite nicely.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Tim Conder with Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, I'll just stay on that a little bit here. Any break down there on Fisher-Price between U.S. and international? And then maybe the infant portion, you seem to call out that, that was  remaining very strong. And then the infant versus non-infant po
componenttext: Richard, I'll just stay on that a little bit here. Any break down there on Fisher-Price between U.S. and international? And then maybe the infant portion, you seem to call out that, that was  remaining very strong. And then the infant versus non-infant portion of Fisher-Price at POS?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think, as I mentioned, across the board, particularly in international, we were really pleased with the Fisher-Price brand overall. Baby, which as we've mentioned, is our biggest and frankly more strategic piece of the business, had positive POS a
componenttext: Sure. I think, as I mentioned, across the board, particularly in international, we were really pleased with the Fisher-Price brand overall. Baby, which as we've mentioned, is our biggest and frankly more strategic piece of the business, had positive POS across all regions. So we're really pleased with the response that we -- our child development messaging certainly has been having. Also, product and pricing had a great impact in the continuation of that trend with Fisher-Price. Generally speaking, as we sort of look ahead, we continued to leverage the momentum that we currently have especially in international markets. The strength across the baby business will continue. There is some amplified marketing as we continue with our Best Possible Start campaign that's gotten a great traction. The continued brand evolution tied to child development is really rich with content and connectivity as we've said, particularly in emerging markets like China. And even as we reenter the preschool learning category more aggressively with our Think and Learn line, the Code-a-Pillar, which I mentioned is a key item for us, is getting a lot of attention and traction. We anticipate that, that will be just one of many early childhood development items that Fisher-Price becomes well known for. Not to belabor the point of Jonathan Adler's appointment, but I think the aesthetic piece of what he'll bring to the overall brand will be important as we move and developed aligned with a bit more fashion sensibility. And, of course, as we mentioned, no content, new partnerships with 9 story, DHX all fuel that particular segment of the brand. So we're confident in our strategic path going forward and certainly, early read in suggesting that we're heading in the right direction.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So will it be fair to say that Fisher-Price is going to be more of an early childhood development versus -- and maybe the preschool part will be somewhat deemphasized on a relatively historical basis?
componenttext: So will it be fair to say that Fisher-Price is going to be more of an early childhood development versus -- and maybe the preschool part will be somewhat deemphasized on a relatively historical basis?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't characterize the quite like that. I would say were going to but a lot more emphasis on the early childhood development and the nursery of the future. But clearly, the rest of the line will continue to get plenty of focus.
componenttext: I wouldn't characterize the quite like that. I would say were going to but a lot more emphasis on the early childhood development and the nursery of the future. But clearly, the rest of the line will continue to get plenty of focus.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And 1 may be housekeeping item here. The impact from Venezuela, was that in or not in on the gross margin? I know you called it out in the EPS side and on the adjusted basis. But on the gross margin basis, was that included in your gross margin numb
componenttext: Okay. And 1 may be housekeeping item here. The impact from Venezuela, was that in or not in on the gross margin? I know you called it out in the EPS side and on the adjusted basis. But on the gross margin basis, was that included in your gross margin number?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that was in other nonoperating losses.
componenttext: No, that was in other nonoperating losses.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay, okay. And then from an inventory perspective, you called out Monster High, you're planning to hopefully exit the year with that sort of stabilized. That was a little bit challenged and in the Latin America as a whole. Any pockets of inventory,
componenttext: Okay, okay, okay. And then from an inventory perspective, you called out Monster High, you're planning to hopefully exit the year with that sort of stabilized. That was a little bit challenged and in the Latin America as a whole. Any pockets of inventory, I guess, brand wise, geographic wise -- when you exited the third quarter of last year, you felt good in a global basis and that really showed up in Q4. So how is that now here sort of in the off-season so to speak?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we made progress in the only place we had overhang in the fourth quarter, which was Brazil. So we made good progress in the first quarter. We're still a bit left, but we'll be through that by the time we get to the all-important second half o
componenttext: Yes, I think we made progress in the only place we had overhang in the fourth quarter, which was Brazil. So we made good progress in the first quarter. We're still a bit left, but we'll be through that by the time we get to the all-important second half of the year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're actually, I think, in a very good shape, Tim, on inventory at this point.
componenttext: We're actually, I think, in a very good shape, Tim, on inventory at this point.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And American Girl, gentleman, would that -- do you feel good where that is? I know you've got a lot of new stuff coming in the back half of the year.
componenttext: And American Girl, gentleman, would that -- do you feel good where that is? I know you've got a lot of new stuff coming in the back half of the year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think there is -- as we've mentioned, we've isolated the brand with a diagnosis that we've now started to execute against. First half, we anticipated would be challenging as we do some pricing strategy, evaluate distribution and reengage with some
componenttext: Yes. I think there is -- as we've mentioned, we've isolated the brand with a diagnosis that we've now started to execute against. First half, we anticipated would be challenging as we do some pricing strategy, evaluate distribution and reengage with some new content, all of which will be executed and revealed in the back half. We're excited about the programs that we have. I think our partnership that we've announced with Amazon is going to bring new content, connectivity to the consumer and sort of reach a broader base consumer. And I think some of the work that the team is doing there will show up on the scoreboard, of course, in the second half. So we're confident with our plants.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just adding to the retail inventory answer, I think what Chris indicated is we're in a much better shape. And I think on a year-over-year basis, that particularly true in Europe.
componenttext: And just adding to the retail inventory answer, I think what Chris indicated is we're in a much better shape. And I think on a year-over-year basis, that particularly true in Europe.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And lastly, Kevin, just a clarification on the hedging. You guys have called out a very favorable hedging that you had in '15. How is the cadence of that? Should we think about use of FX a bit more favorable in the back of the year just on the rates
componenttext: Okay. And lastly, Kevin, just a clarification on the hedging. You guys have called out a very favorable hedging that you had in '15. How is the cadence of that? Should we think about use of FX a bit more favorable in the back of the year just on the rates are? But where did you have the best hedges on? I guess, would create the most difficult comparisons in '15.

componenttextpreview: I think that was really in the first half of the year. As I said in the first half of the year, the year-over-year gross margin rate was favorably impacted by 100 basis points or in the second half of the year, it was unfavorable by 200 basis points.
componenttext: I think that was really in the first half of the year. As I said in the first half of the year, the year-over-year gross margin rate was favorably impacted by 100 basis points or in the second half of the year, it was unfavorable by 200 basis points.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You didn't mention that. My apologies there.
componenttext: Okay. You didn't mention that. My apologies there.

componenttextpreview: Tim, most of that was in the euro, by the way. Right? That was all down this year.
componenttext: Tim, most of that was in the euro, by the way. Right? That was all down this year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Chartier with Monness, Crespi, Hardt.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Jim Chartier with Monness, Crespi, Hardt.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to circle back on the gross margin, Kevin. You're looking at the full year outlook, $125 million to $135 million of cost savings and $46 million realized in the first quarter. It looks like the rest of the year, the cost saves will have a smalle
componenttext: Just want to circle back on the gross margin, Kevin. You're looking at the full year outlook, $125 million to $135 million of cost savings and $46 million realized in the first quarter. It looks like the rest of the year, the cost saves will have a smaller impact as a percentage of sales on margins. So is there more than just the Funding Our Future cost savings embedded in the improvement in second half gross margins? You talk to us to some structural changes there.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think as we said, our Funding Our Future is part of what we're doing. We're on track to deliver at the high end of the range. But we have incremental programs around structural cost savings related to cost of goods sold as well as SG&A that will be
componenttext: Yes. I think as we said, our Funding Our Future is part of what we're doing. We're on track to deliver at the high end of the range. But we have incremental programs around structural cost savings related to cost of goods sold as well as SG&A that will be in excess of what Funding Our Future is. So as we look at the cadence of the year, the inventory that we're selling in the first quarter we produced last year. As I said on the call earlier, that as we ramp up our seasonal production in the second quarter and get peak production in the third quarter, we should see more flow-through from these structural savings in the second half of the year. And that will help us, as I said, to improve our year-over-year gross margins in the second half of the year along with better mix and less impact of foreign exchange in the second half of the year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just to clarify, Fuhu and Sproutling acquisitions, will they be neutral to EPS this year and then accretive next year? Is that the plan?
componenttext: Okay. And just to clarify, Fuhu and Sproutling acquisitions, will they be neutral to EPS this year and then accretive next year? Is that the plan?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, we should be adding top line revenues for the year. And we are adding SG&A, but from a perspective of looking at those operations, we expect them to be breakeven for this year and hopefully, accretive next year.
componenttext: Yes. So overall, we should be adding top line revenues for the year. And we are adding SG&A, but from a perspective of looking at those operations, we expect them to be breakeven for this year and hopefully, accretive next year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Gerrick Johnson of BMO.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Gerrick Johnson of BMO.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about Barbie for a second? The disconnect between the U.S., up 11% and international down 7% in local, and we haven't had a positive quarter in Barbie international since 2013. So what's the difference? Why are they doing well here and not out
componenttext: Can we talk about Barbie for a second? The disconnect between the U.S., up 11% and international down 7% in local, and we haven't had a positive quarter in Barbie international since 2013. So what's the difference? Why are they doing well here and not out there?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, we've always watched it and certainly, we have enough is to be in this brand. North America tends to lead the brand's narrative, both in messaging and in product connectivity as well as retail execution. It tends to be part of the history of the
componenttext: I think, we've always watched it and certainly, we have enough is to be in this brand. North America tends to lead the brand's narrative, both in messaging and in product connectivity as well as retail execution. It tends to be part of the history of the brand and as we see, North America really start to get traction in connectivity, both at retail execution and with consumers, those programs take shape sort of the tail, if you will, and international market a bit later. And when you digest it at least dissect international markets, there's develop ---ed developing markets, there's developed markets and there's a variety of different things that going to the play of the brand. But overall, what we're seeing now is the up getting traction on POS with Barbie. Asia also getting traction on POS Barbie. Latin America is still catching up. We have some work to do in Latin America. But overall, we're seeing great connectivity. Frankly, the successful campaign that we ran this year, the You Can Be Anything campaign that was slightly acclaimed didn't get executed throughout international, so that's still new in some cases and rolling out as we speak. Some of the new product that we launched year in the U.S. is also executed later in certain markets. Our DVD calendar in terms of distribution and marketing is also slightly different in international markets, so I think overall, I would take a look at the Domino of the business being North America at the lead indicator of where the brand should be going and could be going. And so far, the indications here are very good and the tail and the context of international is catching up.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So in what markets were the new fashionista Barbie dolls launched? Was it U.S. and what other markets are these dolls currently in?
componenttext: Okay. So in what markets were the new fashionista Barbie dolls launched? Was it U.S. and what other markets are these dolls currently in?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: They are currently rolling out now. In fact, they are just getting, I think, shelves in Europe more significant in that other markets. As you look at the Barbie brand, as you know, we have segmentation strategies or there's variety of different segments o
componenttext: They are currently rolling out now. In fact, they are just getting, I think, shelves in Europe more significant in that other markets. As you look at the Barbie brand, as you know, we have segmentation strategies or there's variety of different segments of the brand. There is an I Can Be segment, there's a fairy segment, there's entertainment segment, there's fashionistas, there's key items. And as we execute against the brand around the world, different countries dial up or down different segments. So difficult to have a peanut butter approach to the answer, but what I would tell you is that the fashionista collection is rolling out more aggressively in Europe. It will get Asia shortly in certain markets in Asia and Latin America, probably in the second half of the year.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one more on dolls. The DC Super Hero Girls, are those in any markets internationally? Are they only in Target here in the U.S.?
componenttext: Okay. And one more on dolls. The DC Super Hero Girls, are those in any markets internationally? Are they only in Target here in the U.S.?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Only in Target here in the U.S. and those will also be rolling out in the back half.
componenttext: Only in Target here in the U.S. and those will also be rolling out in the back half.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Taposh Bari with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Taposh Bari with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask a question on sales in the quarter versus your expectations. It sounds like you're pretty pleased with the underlying sales momentum despite the fact that you lost the case and the fact that, that impact was proportionately large in the qu
componenttext: I wanted to ask a question on sales in the quarter versus your expectations. It sounds like you're pretty pleased with the underlying sales momentum despite the fact that you lost the case and the fact that, that impact was proportionately large in the quarter. So can you give us a sense on how POS and/or shipments kind of realized versus your expectations? And if Easter has any effect on the reported numbers?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Taposh. We actually normalized Easter. So it's important to understand, we took out any of that effect. And so the numbers you're seeing, I think, are fairly pure as you would look at it. I would say overall, we're actually very enthused by the outco
componenttext: Yes, Taposh. We actually normalized Easter. So it's important to understand, we took out any of that effect. And so the numbers you're seeing, I think, are fairly pure as you would look at it. I would say overall, we're actually very enthused by the outcome of the first quarter. I think we actually probably exceeded a little bit what we had hoped to do, and I think it was very broad-based, which was encouraging. And not just the core brands, but the Toy Box kicked in a lot of meaningful ways. And I think as we tried to indicate, we felt were well-positioned for what we've been guiding for the full year, and I think this is just a good early start. But again, broad-based in both shipping and POS.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just a follow-up on both entertainment on the construction segment lines, you have some big increases there, presumably due to some of these licensed properties that you're taking on this year. Trying to get a better sense for if there was anyt
componenttext: Great. And just a follow-up on both entertainment on the construction segment lines, you have some big increases there, presumably due to some of these licensed properties that you're taking on this year. Trying to get a better sense for if there was anything unique to the first quarter, given that you're probably still in the channel for some of these product lines? In other words, should we expect to see continued robust growth rates in the segments throughout the year, especially as you roll out the DC Super Hero Girls line and also enter the Ninja Turtles theatrical window.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Go ahead, Richard.
componenttext: Go ahead, Richard.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think specifically for MEGA, we -- as I mentioned, introduced some of our brands in the construction category. American Girl has been a resounding success out of the gate. Monster High, also connecting very well in construction. And of course, Tee
componenttext: Well, I think specifically for MEGA, we -- as I mentioned, introduced some of our brands in the construction category. American Girl has been a resounding success out of the gate. Monster High, also connecting very well in construction. And of course, Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles is launching in the movie has that started and we're relatively pleased with that progress. And as you know, the preschool segment of MEGA is robust and doing well. So we anticipate that, that will get better and better as we execute against those properties and introduce others as time moves on. So I think overall in general, we're really pleased with where we're moving and I think it's just going to continue momentum.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The other thing I would add on MEGA is that a lot of that growth also came internationally, so it's not structurally tied either and then payment property on one of our own brands per se. We're expanding, we're getting distribution, we're getting better e
componenttext: The other thing I would add on MEGA is that a lot of that growth also came internationally, so it's not structurally tied either and then payment property on one of our own brands per se. We're expanding, we're getting distribution, we're getting better execution against it.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one last one. Last year in 2015, as the year where you're really increasing spending in terms of supporting the trade. As you think about 2016, [ph] it looks like advertising was down, your sales adjustments were flat year-over-year even though you're
componenttext: And one last one. Last year in 2015, as the year where you're really increasing spending in terms of supporting the trade. As you think about 2016, [ph] it looks like advertising was down, your sales adjustments were flat year-over-year even though you're guiding for it to be up. Help us better understand how you're thinking about supporting the trade in 2016?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just talk about it from a financial perspective and then Richard can talk about it from more execution. But I think as we did our 2016 outlook, we really said we reinstated our sales adjustment from a planning perspective to be at a higher rate than
componenttext: I'll just talk about it from a financial perspective and then Richard can talk about it from more execution. But I think as we did our 2016 outlook, we really said we reinstated our sales adjustment from a planning perspective to be at a higher rate than we experienced in 2014. So we would make sure that we would drive POS this year. Whether we spend that or not will depend upon how our POS performance in the second half of the year. But that's the way we put the financial plan together.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And speaking specifically on behalf of the retail execution, we continue to have those reserves and be ready to drive the various different forms of execution to ensure retail success, whether or not those application is used or not. And then on the overa
componenttext: And speaking specifically on behalf of the retail execution, we continue to have those reserves and be ready to drive the various different forms of execution to ensure retail success, whether or not those application is used or not. And then on the overall advertising side, we continue to get much more intelligent in the context of what works and what does that in our media spend and that will continue to evolve, so much of our advertising moves around and gets we deployed these and what we believe is going to have better connectivity. And as you know, that's a moving target as our consumer constantly changes and new forms of connectivity or introduced constantly. So we are very much on top of that as well.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I think going out to our plan, I think we also plan advertising to be less getting closer to the midpoint of our 11% to 13% range. But also, we need to drive POS, then we will invest what's necessary in advertising to do that.
componenttext: And I think going out to our plan, I think we also plan advertising to be less getting closer to the midpoint of our 11% to 13% range. But also, we need to drive POS, then we will invest what's necessary in advertising to do that.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was going to say the one thing to keep in mind in advertising. Most of the scale back is in what we would call nonworking. So the actual impact on advertising going against the consumer is not being reduced. It's more effectively deployed, but it's the
componenttext: I was going to say the one thing to keep in mind in advertising. Most of the scale back is in what we would call nonworking. So the actual impact on advertising going against the consumer is not being reduced. It's more effectively deployed, but it's the nonworking production stuff that we've been shaving.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of Linda Bolton-Weiser, B. Riley.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Linda Bolton-Weiser, B. Riley.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to circle back once more on Barbie. Again, on that international decline in the Barbie shipments in constant currency, when Richard was talking about it, he said that Barbie was, I think you used the word gaining traction or something in Europe and A
componenttext: Just to circle back once more on Barbie. Again, on that international decline in the Barbie shipments in constant currency, when Richard was talking about it, he said that Barbie was, I think you used the word gaining traction or something in Europe and Asia. So does that mean improving, but still down POS? And that down POS carbonates of the down shipments? Or do we still have like some kind of inventory problem in the channel? So in other words, POS essentially kind of growing, but you still have inventory too high in certain markets? Can you just explain a little bit more?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Linda. Let me be more specific that the POS momentum in Barbie Israel in the international marketplace, specifically in Europe and in Asia. Now it varies by country, but overall, we're seeing great positive traction on POS, some in the lower single
componenttext: Sure, Linda. Let me be more specific that the POS momentum in Barbie Israel in the international marketplace, specifically in Europe and in Asia. Now it varies by country, but overall, we're seeing great positive traction on POS, some in the lower single digits and some of the higher. But generally speaking, gaining more and more momentum. We continue to look at Latin America and to some extent sort of catching up. There's some programs that we're launching there and some various different challenges that we had in that marketplace. But it is moving along. It's a smaller percentage of the total, but in general, we're seeing more green shoots with Barbie across the world.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And final point. There is no inventory issue, if that was your other question, Linda.
componenttext: And final point. There is no inventory issue, if that was your other question, Linda.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So then we should start to see that shipment pattern improve for the international piece of Barbie, it sounds like?
componenttext: Okay. So then we should start to see that shipment pattern improve for the international piece of Barbie, it sounds like?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We will expect so.
componenttext: We will expect so.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes.
componenttext: Yes, yes.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then can you just clarify how much of the Batman v Superman product is shipped in the first quarter? Is it a significant bigger shipment in the second quarter?
componenttext: And then can you just clarify how much of the Batman v Superman product is shipped in the first quarter? Is it a significant bigger shipment in the second quarter?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I don't think it's significantly bigger. I think there'll be -- no, because we sort of filled the shelves up in the first and we are continuing to restock in the second and introduced some new items. So what is it going to be significantly bigger, no.
componenttext: No, I don't think it's significantly bigger. I think there'll be -- no, because we sort of filled the shelves up in the first and we are continuing to restock in the second and introduced some new items. So what is it going to be significantly bigger, no.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then finally, Kevin, on the cash flow performance in the quarter, you mentioned that working capital use some more cash than last year. What are your thoughts on that for the full year? Are you thinking working capital can be a modest source of
componenttext: Okay. And then finally, Kevin, on the cash flow performance in the quarter, you mentioned that working capital use some more cash than last year. What are your thoughts on that for the full year? Are you thinking working capital can be a modest source of use of cash?

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think what we said when we did the outlook that in a challenging year, we delivered strong cash flow in 2015 and we expect cash flow to be a little bit better in 2016. And we're still focused on tightly managing working capital. And I think there'
componenttext: Look, I think what we said when we did the outlook that in a challenging year, we delivered strong cash flow in 2015 and we expect cash flow to be a little bit better in 2016. And we're still focused on tightly managing working capital. And I think there's an opportunity for us to as we exit the year to tightly manage inventories that are a little bit higher that our historical rates. And through better information, technology, better planning process and trying to shorten lead times, we think there's an opportunity to exit the year with working capitals been positive.

headline: Mattel, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Greg, we described our plan without a super bullet, right? So I think the collection of our brand momentum I think will contribute to the momentum. And we've been presently surprised, as I mentioned, with a lot of the Toy Box initiative. Some of these sma
componenttext: Greg, we described our plan without a super bullet, right? So I think the collection of our brand momentum I think will contribute to the momentum. And we've been presently surprised, as I mentioned, with a lot of the Toy Box initiative. Some of these smaller brands are really showing up on the score board and incrementing our expectations. But as we've said, Hot Wheels, Barbie, Fisher-Price, Thomas, specifically our continuing to deliver and certainly will have a strong back half as planned. And then as we drive some of our entertainment relationships that are incremental like Warner Bros, that will drive momentum. MEGA continues to gain traction. And I think as you look at our brands in the construction space, it's all very new business for us and we're excited with that continuing to build in the construction category, which, as you know, is a successful growing category in the industry. And then there's a variety of other new things that we're excited to introduce. Michey Qs is a new brand for us that's going to be launching to the Toy Box. And innovative items like ThingMaker, which we introduced at Toy Fair, is getting a lot of traction and interest. And it symbolizes the innovation and invention aspect that we are driving as part of our new culture. So we believe we've got all our ducks in a well and that was I mentioned, it's really about the execution of it mattering more.
